values.alignmentText: Medical tech leader Dräger, logistics firms, and the Lübeck port authority maintain .NET teams, though roles remain tied to German-language operations.
Beyond small indies and university labs, Lübeck lacks dedicated studios, so Trey relies on remote-first collaborations for game work.
Tourism and limited Altstadt stock keep rents around €12/m², so we target family flats in St. Jürgen or St. Lorenz for better value.
Tourism keeps English serviceable in cafes, yet municipal offices and childcare lean heavily on German.
Media Docks coworking, university parent groups, and international choir circles help newcomers find community with a bit of initiative.
Port digitization and medtech labs are modern, but some neighborhoods still await fiber rollouts.
Baltic beaches at Travemünde, canoeing on the Wakenitz, and forested nature reserves deliver frequent outdoor escapes.
Students keep bars lively and the Musik- und Kongresshalle hosts concerts, though big tours stick to Hamburg.
Technikzentrum Lübeck and Northern Germany creative grants offer seed support, yet scaling a studio would involve tapping Hamburg or Copenhagen networks.
A harbor pace, seaside weekends, and small-city commutes align with Sarah’s preference for slower days.
Bus networks and hourly trains to Hamburg or the Baltic resorts cover essentials, but lack of trams means more planning for cross-town trips.
Many professionals commute to Hamburg part-time, so hybrid and remote schedules are becoming more accepted locally.
Lübeck remains notably safe, letting the kids explore the UNESCO old town with minimal worry.
Senior engineers earn €55–60k in Lübeck’s medtech and logistics sector, balanced by manageable living costs.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries

values.alignmentText: A Hanseatic UNESCO core paired with quick Baltic swims gives the family storybook scenery and coastal downtime.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)

values.alignmentText: Intentional communities exist but are limited in size or geared toward niche demographics. Community Vibes at 7/10, Meetups & Communities at 6/10, and Family Life at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for community living opportunities.

Friendliness varies by neighborhood; we can cultivate ties but must invest time and select communities carefully. Community Vibes at 7/10, Meetups & Communities at 6/10, and Common Hobbies at 9/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for friendliness & neighborliness index.

Sentiment splits; friendly communities exist but national discourse can turn skeptical. Welcoming of US Migrants at 7/10, Progressivism at 8/10, and Language & English Ubiquity at 6/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for immigrant sentiment – general.

Reception depends on class and language; we must adapt quickly to avoid perceptions of aloofness. Welcoming of US Migrants at 7/10, Language & English Ubiquity at 6/10, and View of Them by Neighboring Countries at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for immigrant sentiment – white migrants.

Many acquaintances stay casual, but dedicated outreach unlocks close friendships over time. Community Vibes at 7/10, Meetups & Communities at 6/10, and What Is Intriguing at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for depth-seeking social norms.

Openness is usually welcomed though some contexts expect diplomacy and softening of hard truths. Progressivism at 8/10, What Is Intriguing at 8/10, and Trust in Government at 7/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for moral, honesty & openness expectations.

Attitudes split; open discussion is fine in urban enclaves yet frowned upon elsewhere. Sex (Attitudes) at 8/10, Nightlife & Music at 6/10, and Community Vibes at 7/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for promiscuity attitudes.

Guns are present yet culturally treated as tools with strong safety expectations. Safety & Crime at 8/10, State Ideology at 9/10, and Political System at 9/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for firearm laws & ownership culture.

Balanced approach: regulated markets exist alongside education and support. Progressivism at 8/10, Political System at 9/10, and Safety & Crime at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for controlled substance policies.

Most enforcement is targeted though occasional crackdowns create unease. Safety & Crime at 8/10, Progressivism at 8/10, and Authoritarian Backsliding Risk at 9/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for drug enforcement climate.

Occasional events occur regionally, prompting situational awareness but not chronic fear. Safety & Crime at 8/10 and Stability at 9/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for mass violence incidence.

Prisons meet international standards with active oversight and restorative programs. Authoritarian Backsliding Risk at 9/10, Safety & Crime at 8/10, and Perceived Corruption at 9/10 steer the family toward an excellent outlook for carceral conditions & prison labor.

Sidewalks cover key areas but drivers often rush, so we stay alert with children. Public Transportation at 6/10, Housing Situation at 6/10, and Nature Access at 9/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for walkability & pedestrian safety.

Processed foods are common but balanced by strong fresh markets. Cost of Living (Optional) at 6/10, Community Health Consciousness at 8/10, and Fresh & International Cuisine Access at 7/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for processed food saturation.

We can meet most cravings but specialty ingredients or restaurants appear sporadically. Nightlife & Music at 6/10, Common Hobbies at 9/10, and Meetups & Communities at 6/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for fresh & international cuisine access.

Recessions hit noticeable segments, requiring flexibility or retraining. Economic Health at 7/10, Remote-Friendly Culture at 6/10, and Typical Software Salaries at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for broader job market resilience.
